grammarPoints.usage: Use 'ser' for permanent or defining characteristics

grammarPoints.meaning: to describe temporary states or conditions
grammarPoints.usage: Use 'estar' for temporary conditions, locations, and emotions
Use 'tener' to show ownership or certain physical traits
Use 'tener' with years to state someone's age

grammarPoints.meaning: to express future plans or intentions
grammarPoints.usage: Use 'ir a' + infinitive verb to talk about future actions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I am going to study Spanish

grammarPoints.usage: Use 'me gusta' (singular) or 'me gustan' (plural) with nouns
Use 'hay' to indicate the existence of something
grammarPoints.example: Hay un gato en la casa
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: There is a cat in the house

grammarPoints.usage: Use to describe actions happening right now
Use '¿Qué?' to ask about things or actions
Use '¿Dónde?' to ask about location
Use '¿Cuándo?' to ask about time
Use '¿Cómo?' to ask about manner or condition
Use '¿Por qué?' to ask for reasons
Use '¿Quién?' to ask about people
Use to ask about quantity, must agree in gender/number
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: How many books do you have?

grammarPoints.usage: Adjectives must agree in gender and number with the noun
Use 'muy' before adjectives to mean 'very'
Use 'también' for positive, 'tampoco' for negative
Place 'no' directly before the verb
Some verbs are followed directly by infinitives
Use 'tener que' to say 'have to' or 'must'
Use 'poder' to say 'can' or 'to be able to'
Use 'querer' to say 'want to' do something

grammarPoints.meaning: to express knowledge of how to do something
grammarPoints.usage: Use 'saber' to say you know how to do something
Pronouns are often omitted in Spanish as verb endings indicate the subject
Use 'de' to indicate possession or where something is from
Use 'a' before infinitives after verbs of movement
Use 'en' to indicate where something is
Use 'con' to indicate accompaniment
Use 'para' to indicate purpose or who something is for
Use to compare two things, showing one has more of a quality
Use to compare two things, showing one has less of a quality
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: It is less expensive than this

grammarPoints.usage: Use to indicate the highest degree of a quality
Use reflexive pronouns (me, te, se, nos, os, se) with reflexive verbs
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: My name is Juan (I call myself Juan)

grammarPoints.usage: Some verbs use indirect object pronouns (me, te, le, nos, os, les)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: My head hurts (The head hurts to me)

grammarPoints.meaning: to express recent past ('just' did something)
grammarPoints.usage: Use to say you just did something recently

grammarPoints.meaning: to express duration of ongoing action
grammarPoints.usage: Use to say how long you've been doing something
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I've been studying Spanish for two years

grammarPoints.usage: Use to indicate how long something has been happening
grammarPoints.example: Vivo aquí desde hace cinco años
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I've been living here for five years

grammarPoints.usage: Use to say how long ago something happened or started
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I've been waiting for two hours

grammarPoints.meaning: using present tense to express near future
grammarPoints.usage: Present tense can indicate future with time expressions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Tomorrow I'm going to the cinema

grammarPoints.usage: Use 'al' + infinitive to mean 'when/upon doing'
Use 'sin' + infinitive to mean 'without doing'
Use to express what happens before another action
grammarPoints.example: Antes de comer, lávate las manos

grammarPoints.usage: Use to express what happens after another action
grammarPoints.example: Después de estudiar, voy a dormir
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: After studying, I'm going to sleep

grammarPoints.usage: Use 'por' with parts of the day
Use 'todos/todas' with time periods for 'every'
grammarPoints.example: Voy al gimnasio todos los días
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I go to the gym every day

grammarPoints.usage: Use 'vez/veces' to indicate how many times
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I eat three times a day

grammarPoints.usage: Use conditional of 'gustar' for polite requests
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Would you like to have a coffee?

grammarPoints.usage: Use 'poder' in question form to ask if you may do something
Use to politely ask someone to do something
